summary: Whole-cell biocatalysts offer high selectivity and are environmentally friendly alternatives to traditional chemical synthesis for producing fine and bulk chemicals. They can achieve yields of up to 20.4-26.5 g/L of 2-phenylethanol, which is significantly higher than chemically synthesized counterparts.
key_claims: Whole-cell biocatalysts provide high selectivity in chemical synthesis.
They are environmentally friendly and can produce natural compounds at a lower cost compared to traditional methods.

_abstract: Whole-cell biocatalysts provide unique advantages and have been widely used for the efficient biosynthesis of valueadded fine and bulk chemicals, as well as pharmaceutically active ingredients. What is more, advances in synthetic biology and metabolic engineering, together with the rapid development of molecular genetic tools, have brought about a renaissance of whole-cell biocatalysis. These rapid advancements mean that whole-cell biocatalysts can increasingly be rationally designed. Genes of heterologous enzymes or synthetic pathways are increasingly being introduced into microbial hosts, and depending on the complexity of the synthetic pathway or the target products, they can enable the production of value-added chemicals from cheap feedstock.
